title: Live updates: Israel and Hezbollah agree to cease-fire in Lebanon, Biden says
description: The deal is set to halt Israel’s war against Hezbollah in Lebanon, in a victory for negotiators after weeks of intense talks.
author: Rebecca Tan, Kelly Kasulis Cho, Adela Suliman
byline: Rebecca Tan, Kelly Kasulis Cho, Adela Suliman, Praveena Somasundaram, Karen DeYoung, Ellen Francis, Bryan Pietsch, Mohamad El Chamaa, Adam Taylor, Maegan Vazquez, Brianna Tucker, Lior Soroka, Tyler Pager, John Hudson, Abbie Cheeseman, Kareem Fahim
excerpt: The deal is set to halt Israel’s war against Hezbollah in Lebanon, in a victory for negotiators after weeks of intense talks.
text: JERUSALEM — Israel and Hezbollah have agreed to a cease-fire deal, President Joe Biden announced Tuesday. The agreement, which passed in a 10-1 vote in Israel’s cabinet, is set to take effect Wednesday at 4 a.m. local time, pausing the year-long conflict in southern Lebanon and northern Israel that has escalated in recent weeks. Still, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned earlier Tuesday that Israel would strike again if the Lebanese militant group violated the agreement. Despite the ongoing negotiations, fighting between Israel and Hezbollah ramped up Tuesday.Live coverage contributors 16Return to menuThe cease-fire deal between Israel and Hezbollah will require “nothing less than the full and unwavering commitment of both parties,” said Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert, the U.N. special coordinator for Lebanon. In a statement Tuesday, she urged them to “restore the safety and security that civilians on both sides of the Blue Line deserve” and avoid “disingenuous implementation” of the agreement.How the cease-fire deal will work, according to a White House officialReturn to menuWhile all fire from both sides will stop at 4 a.m. local time — 9 p.m. Eastern — Israeli troops will hold their positions and will not immediately withdraw, according to a senior Biden administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under rules set by the White House.Return to menuIsrael has issued evacuation notices for Beirut’s southern suburbs, as it has carried out strikes there and in other parts of Lebanon over the last day and intensified them in the hours before the cease-fire deal with Hezbollah will take effect. Over the last three hours, Lebanon’s public health ministry has been reporting deaths and injuries from raids in a number of towns and neighborhoods.Return to menuThe agreement is for a 60-day cessation of hostilities, with plans for a coordinated withdrawal of Israeli soldiers and a deployment of the Lebanese army to restore Lebanese sovereignty south of the Litani river and prevent the use of weapons by Hezbollah militants there, according to officials familiar with the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive diplomacy.The aim is to work toward a more long-term, durable solution during the cease-fire, the officials said.Return to menuIsraeli National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir called the decision to approve the cease-fire deal a “grave mistake.” He said the agreement would not be enough to return residents of northern Israel to their homes and would not deter Hezbollah.The deal, he said, costs Israel an “historic opportunity to deliver a severe blow [to Hezbollah] and bring them to their knees.”Lebanese prime minister speaks with Biden Return to menuLebanon’s caretaker prime minister, Najib Mikati, spoke with President Joe Biden on Tuesday about the cease-fire deal, Mikati’s office said in a statement.Mikati thanked Biden and U.S. envoy Amos Hochstein for their efforts to reach an agreement, adding that he considers the deal a “fundamental step towards establishing calm and stability in Lebanon and the return of the displaced to their homes and cities.”Return to menuIn a joint statement, President Joe Biden and French President Emmanuel Macron said that the cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon would “create the conditions to restore lasting calm and allow residents in both countries to return safely to their homes.” Both leaders pledged to work to ensure the cease-fire is fully implemented, the statement said.Return to menuAfter President Joe Biden delivered remarks at the White House focused on the new cease-fire agreement between Israel and Lebanon, a reporter asked him if he would be able to achieve a cease-fire with Gaza before leaving office.“I think so. I hope so. I’m praying,” Biden responded, according to the press pool.Biden says people of Gaza deserve an end to the fightingReturn to menuIn his remarks at the White House on Tuesday announcing a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah over fighting in Lebanon, President Joe Biden described the deal as “a new start” for Lebanon and called for an end to the war in Gaza.“Just as the Lebanese people deserve a future of security and prosperity, so do the people of Gaza. They, too, deserve an end to the fighting and displacement. The people of Gaza have been through hell,” he said.Biden on cease-fire deal: ‘This is designed to be a permanent cessation of hostilities’Return to menuPresident Joe Biden delivered remarks on Tuesday outlining the new cease-fire agreement between Israel and Lebanon, saying that he spoke to the prime ministers of both nations before his speech in the White House Rose Garden."I am pleased to announce that their governments have accepted the United States proposal to end the devastating conflict between Israel and Hezbollah,” Biden said.Return to menuIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke with President Joe Biden Tuesday, according to a statement put out by the prime minister’s office. According to the statement, Netanyahu thanked Biden “for the United States’ involvement in reaching the cease-fire agreement in Lebanon and for understanding that Israel will maintain freedom of action in its enforcement.”Return to menuIsrael has approved the U.S. proposal for a cease-fire in Lebanon, the Israeli prime minister’s office said in a statement Tuesday. The proposal was accepted after a vote at Israel’s Security Cabinet, with 10 ministers supporting and only one opposing, according to the statement. The cease-fire is expected to begin tomorrow morning local time, though the statement did not specify the time.Netanyahu says he will present cease-fire proposal to Israeli ministersReturn to menuIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a video statement Tuesday that he was presenting a “framework for cease-fire” in Lebanon to his government cabinet on Tuesday evening, upping the pressure on ministers to accept.“The duration of the cease-fire will depend on developments in Lebanon,” Netanyahu said in the recorded video, adding that Israel had coordinated with the United States the ability to retain full “military freedom of action.”Return to menuPresident Joe Biden will speak at 2:30 p.m. Eastern time from the Rose Garden, where he is expected to address the latest efforts to achieve a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.Return to menuThe Israel Defense Forces said that approximately 65 projectiles were fired into Israel from Lebanon on Tuesday. Despite ongoing cease-fire talks and public statements by diplomats about the increasing possibility of a deal, fighting between Israel and Hezbollah has not abated.Return to menuSecretary of State Antony Blinken told reporters on the sidelines of the Group of Seven meeting in Italy that the United States is in the “final stages” of securing a cease-fire agreement with Hezbollah.“If we get to the conclusion that I hope we reach very soon, it will make a big difference,” Blinken said. “It will make a big difference in saving lives and livelihoods in Lebanon and in Israel. It will make a big difference in creating the conditions that will allow people to return to their homes safely in northern Israel and in southern Lebanon. And I also believe that by de-escalating tensions in the region, it can also help us to end the conflict in Gaza.”Return to menuIntensifying winter weather is causing flooding in southern Gaza. In Khan Younis, families in tents are facing heavy rains and rising sea levels, compounding misery for those displaced, the United Nations said Tuesday on X.Return to menuIsrael “outright denied” 82 out of 91 attempts since Oct. 26 to deliver aid to cut-off areas in northern Gaza, said Georgios Petropoulos, head of the U.N. humanitarian office in Gaza, in a statement. Still more attempts were unsuccessful because of “denials of specific locations or specific supplies,” he said.The Israel Defense Forces did not immediately respond to a request for comment.Return to menuThe Israeli government said Tuesday that 78 people were killed by Hezbollah and its allies between Oct. 7, 2023, and Nov. 21, 2024. Of those people, 41 were Israeli civilians, six were foreign civilians and 31 were members of security forces. The prime minister’s office said 764 people have been injured, while 46,561 were evacuated from Israel’s northern regions.In the same period in Lebanon, 3,645 people were killed and 15,355 were injured, according to Lebanese government data, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians. More than 25 percent of those killed were women and children, according to the government data.Correction: This post originally misstated the number of people evacuated from Israel’s northern regions. The figure is 46,561. The post has been corrected.Return to menuThe Israel Defense Forces issued evacuation orders for more than 20 locations in Beirut’s suburbs and announced that it was carrying out strikes on Hezbollah targets in the Lebanese capital. A multistory building in Beirut’s Nuwairi area was struck in the afternoon, killing at least three people, Lebanon’s Health Ministry said in an initial toll. It marked the fifth strike on central Beirut in the past two weeks.Return to menuThe Israel Defense Forces issued evacuation orders for four areas of central Beirut for the first time — though Israel has previously struck central Beirut without warning. The Israeli military issued more of these warnings for specific buildings Tuesday than it has on any other day of the war.Return to menuThe Israeli military said Tuesday on social media that its troops have reached Lebanon’s Litani River. Their position, if confirmed, would mark a significant advance, placing Israeli troops somewhere along the geographical boundary cited in the cease-fire proposal. Hezbollah fighters would be required to withdraw north of the river under the deal.Gaza civil defense says rescue vehicles have stopped operating due to lack of fuelReturn to menuJERUSALEM — Lack of fuel is crippling emergency and public services in Gaza, Palestinian civil service agencies said Tuesday.The Palestinian Civil Defense agency said all 32 of its remaining fire, rescue and ambulance vehicles inside Gaza have stopped operating due to a lack of fuel. The agency last week warned that it only had enough supplies to operate one water tanker and one rescue vehicle inside the territory of more than 2 million residents.International Criminal Court has no jurisdiction in Gaza, U.S. saysReturn to menuState Department spokesman Matthew Miller offered a technical critique Monday of the International Criminal Court’s arrest warrant for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, reiterating a long-standing U.S. argument.Israeli cabinet to convene Tuesday to discuss Hezbollah cease-fire dealReturn to menuJERUSALEM — Israel’s cabinet will convene Tuesday to discuss details of a U.S.-backed cease-fire agreement with Hezbollah, according to a spokesman for the Israeli prime minister.Intense negotiations over the past week have brought the two sides closer, but the deal has not yet been finalized, according to Israeli, Lebanese and Western officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity Monday to discuss the precarious negotiations.Monitoring the status of hostages still in Gaza after Hamas’s attackIsraeli military deaths in Lebanon raise questions over war’s scope Israel prepares Lebanon cease-fire plan as ‘gift’ to Trump, officials say
html:
JERUSALEM — Israel and Hezbollah have agreed to a cease-fire deal, President Joe Biden announced Tuesday. The agreement, which passed in a 10-1 vote in Israel’s cabinet, is set to take effect Wednesday at 4 a.m. local time, pausing the year-long conflict in southern Lebanon and northern Israel that has escalated in recent weeks. Still, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned earlier Tuesday that Israel would strike again if the Lebanese militant group violated the agreement. Despite the ongoing negotiations, fighting between Israel and Hezbollah ramped up Tuesday.

Live coverage contributors 16

  • Return to menu

    The cease-fire deal between Israel and Hezbollah will require “nothing less than the full and unwavering commitment of both parties,” said Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert, the U.N. special coordinator for Lebanon. In a statement Tuesday, she urged them to “restore the safety and security that civilians on both sides of the Blue Line deserve” and avoid “disingenuous implementation” of the agreement.

  • How the cease-fire deal will work, according to a White House official

    Return to menu

    While all fire from both sides will stop at 4 a.m. local time — 9 p.m. Eastern — Israeli troops will hold their positions and will not immediately withdraw, according to a senior Biden administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under rules set by the White House.

  • Return to menu

    Israel has issued evacuation notices for Beirut’s southern suburbs, as it has carried out strikes there and in other parts of Lebanon over the last day and intensified them in the hours before the cease-fire deal with Hezbollah will take effect. Over the last three hours, Lebanon’s public health ministry has been reporting deaths and injuries from raids in a number of towns and neighborhoods.

  • Return to menu

    The agreement is for a 60-day cessation of hostilities, with plans for a coordinated withdrawal of Israeli soldiers and a deployment of the Lebanese army to restore Lebanese sovereignty south of the Litani river and prevent the use of weapons by Hezbollah militants there, according to officials familiar with the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive diplomacy.

    The aim is to work toward a more long-term, durable solution during the cease-fire, the officials said.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir called the decision to approve the cease-fire deal a “grave mistake.” He said the agreement would not be enough to return residents of northern Israel to their homes and would not deter Hezbollah.

    The deal, he said, costs Israel an “historic opportunity to deliver a severe blow [to Hezbollah] and bring them to their knees.”

  • Lebanese prime minister speaks with Biden

    Return to menu

    Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister, Najib Mikati, spoke with President Joe Biden on Tuesday about the cease-fire deal, Mikati’s office said in a statement.

    Mikati thanked Biden and U.S. envoy Amos Hochstein for their efforts to reach an agreement, adding that he considers the deal a “fundamental step towards establishing calm and stability in Lebanon and the return of the displaced to their homes and cities.”

  • Return to menu

    In a joint statement, President Joe Biden and French President Emmanuel Macron said that the cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon would “create the conditions to restore lasting calm and allow residents in both countries to return safely to their homes.” Both leaders pledged to work to ensure the cease-fire is fully implemented, the statement said.

  • Return to menu

    After President Joe Biden delivered remarks at the White House focused on the new cease-fire agreement between Israel and Lebanon, a reporter asked him if he would be able to achieve a cease-fire with Gaza before leaving office.

    “I think so. I hope so. I’m praying,” Biden responded, according to the press pool.

  • Biden says people of Gaza deserve an end to the fighting

    Return to menu

    In his remarks at the White House on Tuesday announcing a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah over fighting in Lebanon, President Joe Biden described the deal as “a new start” for Lebanon and called for an end to the war in Gaza.

    “Just as the Lebanese people deserve a future of security and prosperity, so do the people of Gaza. They, too, deserve an end to the fighting and displacement. The people of Gaza have been through hell,” he said.

  • Biden on cease-fire deal: ‘This is designed to be a permanent cessation of hostilities’

    Return to menu

    President Joe Biden delivered remarks on Tuesday outlining the new cease-fire agreement between Israel and Lebanon, saying that he spoke to the prime ministers of both nations before his speech in the White House Rose Garden.

    "I am pleased to announce that their governments have accepted the United States proposal to end the devastating conflict between Israel and Hezbollah,” Biden said.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke with President Joe Biden Tuesday, according to a statement put out by the prime minister’s office. According to the statement, Netanyahu thanked Biden “for the United States’ involvement in reaching the cease-fire agreement in Lebanon and for understanding that Israel will maintain freedom of action in its enforcement.”

  • Return to menu

    Israel has approved the U.S. proposal for a cease-fire in Lebanon, the Israeli prime minister’s office said in a statement Tuesday. The proposal was accepted after a vote at Israel’s Security Cabinet, with 10 ministers supporting and only one opposing, according to the statement. The cease-fire is expected to begin tomorrow morning local time, though the statement did not specify the time.

  • Netanyahu says he will present cease-fire proposal to Israeli ministers

    Return to menu

    Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a video statement Tuesday that he was presenting a “framework for cease-fire” in Lebanon to his government cabinet on Tuesday evening, upping the pressure on ministers to accept.

    “The duration of the cease-fire will depend on developments in Lebanon,” Netanyahu said in the recorded video, adding that Israel had coordinated with the United States the ability to retain full “military freedom of action.”

  • Return to menu

    President Joe Biden will speak at 2:30 p.m. Eastern time from the Rose Garden, where he is expected to address the latest efforts to achieve a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.

  • Return to menu

    The Israel Defense Forces said that approximately 65 projectiles were fired into Israel from Lebanon on Tuesday. Despite ongoing cease-fire talks and public statements by diplomats about the increasing possibility of a deal, fighting between Israel and Hezbollah has not abated.

  • Return to menu

    Secretary of State Antony Blinken told reporters on the sidelines of the Group of Seven meeting in Italy that the United States is in the “final stages” of securing a cease-fire agreement with Hezbollah.

    “If we get to the conclusion that I hope we reach very soon, it will make a big difference,” Blinken said. “It will make a big difference in saving lives and livelihoods in Lebanon and in Israel. It will make a big difference in creating the conditions that will allow people to return to their homes safely in northern Israel and in southern Lebanon. And I also believe that by de-escalating tensions in the region, it can also help us to end the conflict in Gaza.”

  • Return to menu

    Intensifying winter weather is causing flooding in southern Gaza. In Khan Younis, families in tents are facing heavy rains and rising sea levels, compounding misery for those displaced, the United Nations said Tuesday on X.

  • Return to menu

    Israel “outright denied” 82 out of 91 attempts since Oct. 26 to deliver aid to cut-off areas in northern Gaza, said Georgios Petropoulos, head of the U.N. humanitarian office in Gaza, in a statement. Still more attempts were unsuccessful because of “denials of specific locations or specific supplies,” he said.

    The Israel Defense Forces did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli government said Tuesday that 78 people were killed by Hezbollah and its allies between Oct. 7, 2023, and Nov. 21, 2024. Of those people, 41 were Israeli civilians, six were foreign civilians and 31 were members of security forces. The prime minister’s office said 764 people have been injured, while 46,561 were evacuated from Israel’s northern regions.

    In the same period in Lebanon, 3,645 people were killed and 15,355 were injured, according to Lebanese government data, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians. More than 25 percent of those killed were women and children, according to the government data.

    Correction: This post originally misstated the number of people evacuated from Israel’s northern regions. The figure is 46,561. The post has been corrected.

  • Return to menu

    The Israel Defense Forces issued evacuation orders for more than 20 locations in Beirut’s suburbs and announced that it was carrying out strikes on Hezbollah targets in the Lebanese capital. A multistory building in Beirut’s Nuwairi area was struck in the afternoon, killing at least three people, Lebanon’s Health Ministry said in an initial toll. It marked the fifth strike on central Beirut in the past two weeks.

  • Return to menu

    The Israel Defense Forces issued evacuation orders for four areas of central Beirut for the first time — though Israel has previously struck central Beirut without warning. The Israeli military issued more of these warnings for specific buildings Tuesday than it has on any other day of the war.

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli military said Tuesday on social media that its troops have reached Lebanon’s Litani River. Their position, if confirmed, would mark a significant advance, placing Israeli troops somewhere along the geographical boundary cited in the cease-fire proposal. Hezbollah fighters would be required to withdraw north of the river under the deal.

  • Gaza civil defense says rescue vehicles have stopped operating due to lack of fuel

    Return to menu

    JERUSALEM — Lack of fuel is crippling emergency and public services in Gaza, Palestinian civil service agencies said Tuesday.

    The Palestinian Civil Defense agency said all 32 of its remaining fire, rescue and ambulance vehicles inside Gaza have stopped operating due to a lack of fuel. The agency last week warned that it only had enough supplies to operate one water tanker and one rescue vehicle inside the territory of more than 2 million residents.

  • International Criminal Court has no jurisdiction in Gaza, U.S. says

    Return to menu

    State Department spokesman Matthew Miller offered a technical critique Monday of the International Criminal Court’s arrest warrant for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, reiterating a long-standing U.S. argument.

  • Israeli cabinet to convene Tuesday to discuss Hezbollah cease-fire deal

    Return to menu

    JERUSALEM — Israel’s cabinet will convene Tuesday to discuss details of a U.S.-backed cease-fire agreement with Hezbollah, according to a spokesman for the Israeli prime minister.

    Intense negotiations over the past week have brought the two sides closer, but the deal has not yet been finalized, according to Israeli, Lebanese and Western officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity Monday to discuss the precarious negotiations.

    • Monitoring the status of hostages still in Gaza after Hamas’s attack

    • Israeli military deaths in Lebanon raise questions over war’s scope 

    • Israel prepares Lebanon cease-fire plan as ‘gift’ to Trump, officials say
